title: Hebrews Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hebrews chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hebrews Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hebrews Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:1, what should believers leave behind to go on unto perfection?
options: The principles of the doctrine of Christ
questions.correctAnswer: The principles of the doctrine of Christ
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:1 instructs believers to leave the principles of the doctrine of Christ and go on unto perfection.

questions.question: Which doctrines are mentioned as foundations not to be laid again in Hebrews 6:2?
options: Repentance from dead works, faith toward God, baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance from dead works, faith toward God, baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:2 lists these teachings as the foundation not to be laid again.

questions.question: Who is said to have made a promise confirmed by an oath in Hebrews 6:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:13 states that God made a promise to Abraham and confirmed it with an oath.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 6:10 say God will not forget?
options: Your work and labour of love
questions.correctAnswer: Your work and labour of love
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:10 assures that God is not unrighteous to forget the work and labour of love shown towards His name.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:19, what is our hope compared to?
questions.correctAnswer: An anchor of the soul
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:19 describes hope as an anchor of the soul, both sure and steadfast.

questions.question: Which forerunner entered within the veil for us, as mentioned in Hebrews 6:20?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:20 states that Jesus entered within the veil as our forerunner and is made a high priest forever.

questions.question: What happens to the earth which brings forth thorns and briers according to Hebrews 6:8?
options: It is rejected and near to cursing, whose end is to be burned
questions.correctAnswer: It is rejected and near to cursing, whose end is to be burned
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:8 explains that earth bearing thorns and briers is rejected and near to cursing, ending in burning.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:4, what is impossible for those who were once enlightened and tasted the heavenly gift?
options: To renew them again unto repentance if they fall away
questions.correctAnswer: To renew them again unto repentance if they fall away
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:4-6 says it is impossible to renew unto repentance those who fall away after being enlightened and tasting the heavenly gift.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 6:3 says that the desire to go on unto perfection will happen only if God permits.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:3 expresses the intention to go on unto perfection if God permits.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 6:12 encourages believers to be slothful and not follow those who inherit the promises through faith and patience.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:12 exhorts believers not to be slothful but to be followers of those who inherit promises through faith and patience.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 6:18 states it is impossible for God to lie.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:18 confirms that by two immutable things it was impossible for God to lie.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Hebrews 6:14: 'Surely blessing I will bless thee, and multiplying I will ______ thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: multiply
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:14 says 'multiplying I will multiply thee' as part of God's promise to Abraham.

questions.question: Which two immutable things provide strong consolation for those who have fled for refuge according to Hebrews 6:18?
questions.correctAnswer: God's promise and His oath
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:17-18 explain that God confirmed His promise by an oath, both immutable, giving strong consolation.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:15, what did Abraham obtain after patiently enduring?
questions.correctAnswer: The promise
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:15 states Abraham obtained the promise after patiently enduring.

questions.question: What is the purpose of God's oath mentioned in Hebrews 6:16?
options: To put an end to all strife
questions.correctAnswer: To put an end to all strife
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:16 explains that an oath for confirmation ends all strife among men.

medium.title: Hebrews Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hebrews Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 6 teach us about progressing in spiritual maturity?
options: Leaving the basic teachings and moving toward perfection
Continuing to repeat foundation teachings without growth
Focusing only on good works without faith
questions.correctAnswer: Leaving the basic teachings and moving toward perfection
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:1 encourages believers to leave the elementary principles of Christ and go on to perfection, showing the importance of spiritual growth beyond basic teachings. This is supported by verses 2 and 3 which mention foundational doctrines but encourage progress.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about their salvation after falling into sin. According to Hebrews 6, what truth would you share about renewing repentance?
options: It is impossible to renew them again to repentance if they fall away
God will always forgive without repentance
They should ignore their sin and continue as before
They must prove their worth through works
questions.correctAnswer: It is impossible to renew them again to repentance if they fall away
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:4-6 explains that those who have been enlightened and then fall away cannot be renewed again to repentance because they crucify the Son of God afresh. This teaches the seriousness of apostasy and the need for perseverance in faith.

questions.question: What principle about Christian service and labor does Hebrews 6 emphasize to encourage believers?
options: God remembers and rewards the work and love shown in ministering to others
Only public ministry counts as labor for God
Labor for God goes unnoticed and is often wasted
Service is unnecessary if faith is strong
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers and rewards the work and love shown in ministering to others
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:10 assures believers that God is not unrighteous to forget their work and labor of love shown toward His name through ministry to the saints, encouraging faithful service.

questions.question: In the context of perseverance, what does Hebrews 6 teach about faith and patience?
options: Followers through faith and patience inherit the promises
Faith alone without patience is sufficient
Patience is not important if faith is strong
Promises are inherited by works only
questions.correctAnswer: Followers through faith and patience inherit the promises
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:12 encourages believers to imitate those who through faith and patience inherit the promises, highlighting the importance of endurance in the Christian walk.

questions.question: Hebrews 6 uses the example of God’s promise to Abraham. What does this teach about God’s faithfulness?
options: God confirmed His promise with an oath because He swears by Himself
God’s promises are uncertain and changeable
God relies on human agreement to keep promises
God does not make promises to individuals
questions.correctAnswer: God confirmed His promise with an oath because He swears by Himself
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:13-17 shows that God made a promise to Abraham and confirmed it with an oath, swearing by Himself because there is no greater, demonstrating the immutability of His counsel and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 6 describe the hope believers have as they endure trials?
options: As an anchor of the soul, sure and steadfast
As a vague wish with no assurance
As a reward earned by works
questions.correctAnswer: As an anchor of the soul, sure and steadfast
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:19 describes the hope set before believers as an anchor for the soul, both sure and steadfast, providing strong consolation and stability during trials.

questions.question: What role does Jesus play according to Hebrews 6 in the believer’s journey of faith?
options: He is the forerunner who entered within the veil as high priest forever
He is only an example to follow
He is a temporary priest serving until replaced
He is distant and not involved in our struggles
questions.correctAnswer: He is the forerunner who entered within the veil as high priest forever
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:20 teaches that Jesus is the forerunner who has entered the inner sanctuary as our eternal high priest, signifying His ongoing intercession and leadership in our faith journey.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 6 teaches that God can lie if it suits His purposes.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:18 states it is impossible for God to lie, highlighting His absolute truthfulness and reliability.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 6 encourages believers to be slothful and neglect diligence in hope.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:11-12 urges believers to show diligence and not be slothful, but to imitate those who inherit the promises through faith and patience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "For the earth which drinketh in the rain that cometh oft upon it, and bringeth forth herbs meet for them by whom it is dressed, receiveth _______ from God."
questions.correctAnswer: blessing
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:7 uses the image of the earth receiving blessing from God when it produces useful crops, illustrating the principle of fruitful Christian living.

questions.question: Based on Hebrews 6, what warning is given about those who produce thorns and briers instead of good fruit?
options: They are near to cursing and their end is to be burned
They will be ignored by God
They will prosper in the world
questions.correctAnswer: They are near to cursing and their end is to be burned
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:8 warns that the earth bringing forth thorns and briers is rejected and close to being cursed, with its end being burned, symbolizing judgment on unfruitfulness.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 6 say about the foundation teachings believers should not lay again?
options: Repentance from dead works and faith toward God
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance from dead works and faith toward God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:1 instructs not to lay again the foundation of repentance from dead works and faith toward God, encouraging believers to move beyond the elementary steps.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 6 describe the assurance believers can have in God's promises?
options: It is strong consolation based on two immutable things
It is uncertain and changes with time
It is based on wishes and hopes
questions.correctAnswer: It is strong consolation based on two immutable things
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:18 explains that God's promise is confirmed by two immutable things—His word and oath—offering believers strong consolation when they take refuge in hope.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 6 teach about diligence in hope until the end?
options: Believers should show diligence to the full assurance of hope unto the end
Hope should be abandoned if trials come
Diligence is only needed at the beginning of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should show diligence to the full assurance of hope unto the end
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:11 encourages all believers to demonstrate the same diligence to maintain full assurance of hope until the end of their faith journey.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6, how should believers respond to those who have fallen away after being enlightened?
options: Be cautious and understand the gravity of falling away as it is impossible to renew them again to repentance
Immediately forgive and ignore the fall
Encourage them to continue without repentance
Assume they will return eventually without effort
questions.correctAnswer: Be cautious and understand the gravity of falling away as it is impossible to renew them again to repentance
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:4-6 warns about the impossibility of renewing again to repentance those who have fallen away after enlightenment, urging believers to take seriously the commitment to faith and perseverance.

hard.title: Hebrews Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hebrews Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Hebrews 6:4-6, what is described as impossible for those who have been enlightened and then fall away?
options: To be renewed again unto repentance
To regain the laying on of hands
To partake in the resurrection of the dead
questions.correctAnswer: To be renewed again unto repentance
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:4-6 explains that it is impossible for those who have once been enlightened and have tasted the heavenly gift to be renewed again unto repentance if they fall away.

questions.question: What does the author of Hebrews use as a metaphor in Hebrews 6:7-8 to illustrate the difference between those who live fruitfully and those who do not?
options: The earth receiving rain and bearing herbs versus thorns and briers
A lamp shining in a dark place
questions.correctAnswer: The earth receiving rain and bearing herbs versus thorns and briers
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:7-8 contrasts the earth that drinks in rain and produces useful herbs with that which produces thorns and briers, symbolizing blessing versus curse.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is cited in Hebrews 6:13-15 as an example of patient endurance leading to the receiving of a promise?
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:13-15 references God's promise to Abraham and how he patiently endured to obtain that promise.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:10, how does God regard the work and labor of love shown by the believers?
options: God is not unrighteous to forget it
questions.correctAnswer: God is not unrighteous to forget it
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:10 states that God is just and will not forget the believers’ work and labor of love toward His name and the saints.

questions.question: What is described as 'an anchor of the soul, both sure and stedfast' in Hebrews 6:19?
questions.correctAnswer: The hope set before us
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:19 metaphorically describes the Christian hope as an anchor of the soul, providing stability and security.

questions.question: In Hebrews 6:18, what two immutable things are mentioned as ensuring it is impossible for God to lie?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promise and His oath
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:17-18 explains God confirmed His counsel by an oath, showing the immutability of His promise and oath, making it impossible for Him to lie.

questions.question: Who is identified in Hebrews 6:20 as the forerunner who has entered within the veil and is made a high priest forever?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:20 describes Jesus as the forerunner who entered the inner sanctuary and is a high priest forever in the order of Melchisedec.

questions.question: What foundational doctrines does Hebrews 6:1-2 instruct believers to leave behind in order to move on to perfection?
options: Repentance from dead works, faith toward God, baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection of the dead, eternal judgment
The laws of Moses and dietary restrictions
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance from dead works, faith toward God, baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection of the dead, eternal judgment
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:1-2 lists these principles as foundational teachings that believers should move beyond toward spiritual maturity.

questions.question: Hebrews 6:12 exhorts believers not to be slothful but to imitate whom?
options: Those who through faith and patience inherit the promises
questions.correctAnswer: Those who through faith and patience inherit the promises
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:12 encourages believers to follow the example of those who inherit God's promises by faith and patience.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:16, men swear by the greater for what purpose?
options: To end all strife with an oath for confirmation
questions.correctAnswer: To end all strife with an oath for confirmation
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:16 explains that swearing by something greater serves to confirm an oath and end disputes.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 6:9 expresses confidence that the readers are associated with salvation despite the warning given.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:9 expresses persuasion of better things and salvation for the readers even though the author gives serious warnings.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 6:14 quotes God's promise to Abraham, saying, 'Surely blessing I will bless thee, and ______ I will multiply thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: multiplying
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:14 quotes the promise to Abraham using the exact phrase 'multiplying I will multiply thee.'

questions.question: What is the significance of the order of Melchisedec mentioned in Hebrews 6:20 in relation to Jesus' priesthood?
options: It foreshadows an eternal and superior priesthood unlike the Levitical priesthood
It indicates Jesus was a Levite
It refers to a temporary priesthood
It suggests a priesthood based on genealogy
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows an eternal and superior priesthood unlike the Levitical priesthood
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:20 shows Jesus as a high priest forever according to Melchisedec's order, which is eternal and superior to Levitical priests.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:11, what attitude does the author desire believers to show until the end?
options: Diligence to the full assurance of hope
questions.correctAnswer: Diligence to the full assurance of hope
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:11 expresses the desire that believers show diligence and full assurance of hope until the end.

questions.question: What cultural practice in the ancient Near East is alluded to in Hebrews 6:17 when describing God’s confirmation of His counsel by an oath?
options: Swearing by something greater to settle disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Swearing by something greater to settle disputes
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:16-17 references the Near Eastern custom of swearing oaths by something greater to confirm promises and end strife.

theological.title: Hebrews Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hebrews Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:1, what should believers move beyond in their spiritual growth?
options: Principles of the doctrine of Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Principles of the doctrine of Christ
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:1 urges believers to leave the elementary teachings about Christ (the foundational principles) and move on to maturity. This aligns with other scriptures encouraging growth beyond basic doctrine (1 Corinthians 3:1-2; 2 Peter 3:18; Ephesians 4:13-15; Colossians 1:28).

questions.question: Which foundational doctrines are mentioned in Hebrews 6:2 as the elementary teachings not to be laid again?
options: Repentance, faith, baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection, eternal judgment
The Ten Commandments, sacrifices, priesthood, temple worship
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance, faith, baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection, eternal judgment
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:2 lists these foundational teachings as the basic doctrines that believers should move beyond. This matches core New Testament teachings (Acts 2:38; Mark 16:16; 1 Corinthians 15:20-23; Revelation 20:11-15).

questions.question: What is described in Hebrews 6:4 as impossible to renew again unto repentance if fallen away?
options: Those once enlightened, tasted heavenly gift, partakers of Holy Ghost
Those who have never heard the Gospel
Those who committed sins in ignorance
Those who have only professed faith outwardly
questions.correctAnswer: Those once enlightened, tasted heavenly gift, partakers of Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:4-6 explains it is impossible to renew to repentance those who were truly enlightened and partook of the Holy Spirit but then fell away, emphasizing the seriousness of apostasy. Similar warnings appear in 2 Peter 2:20-22; John 10:27-29; 1 John 2:19; Matthew 12:31-32.

questions.question: In Hebrews 6:6, what consequence is given for those who fall away after receiving enlightenment and the Holy Spirit?
options: They crucify the Son of God afresh and put Him to open shame
They are forgiven if they repent again
They become ministers in the church
questions.correctAnswer: They crucify the Son of God afresh and put Him to open shame
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:6 states that falling away after enlightenment is akin to crucifying Christ anew and dishonoring Him. This reflects the gravity of apostasy and aligns with passages like Galatians 5:4; John 15:6; 1 Corinthians 1:23; Luke 23:34.

questions.question: What analogy does Hebrews 6:7-8 use to describe the outcome of those who receive God's blessing versus those who produce thorns and briers?
options: Earth that drinks rain and produces useful herbs versus earth that produces thorns and briers
A fruitful tree versus a barren tree
A sheep in a green pasture versus a lost sheep
A wise builder versus a foolish builder
questions.correctAnswer: Earth that drinks rain and produces useful herbs versus earth that produces thorns and briers
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:7-8 compares the earth that receives rain and produces useful plants to those who live godly lives, receiving blessing, while those producing thorns are rejected and near cursing, consistent with Jesus’ parables (Matthew 13:3-9, 18-23; Jeremiah 17:5-6; Isaiah 5:1-7; Luke 6:43-45).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 6:10, why does God not forget the work and labor of love shown by believers?
options: Because it is done toward His name by ministering to the saints
Because it makes them popular among people
Because it guarantees entrance into heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is done toward His name by ministering to the saints
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:10 teaches that God remembers the loving works done in His name, especially ministering to fellow believers, reflecting God's justice and care for His people (Matthew 25:40; Galatians 6:9-10; 1 John 3:17-18; James 1:27).

questions.question: What attitude does Hebrews 6:11 encourage believers to exhibit toward hope until the end?
options: Diligence to the full assurance of hope
questions.correctAnswer: Diligence to the full assurance of hope
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:11 urges believers to show persistent effort and confidence in the hope of salvation, consistent with Paul's exhortations (Romans 5:2; Colossians 1:23; 1 Thessalonians 5:8; James 1:12).

questions.question: Who are believers exhorted to imitate according to Hebrews 6:12?
options: Those who through faith and patience inherit the promises
The wise men of the world
questions.correctAnswer: Those who through faith and patience inherit the promises
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:12 calls believers to not be lazy but to imitate those who inherit God's promises through faith and patience, reflecting biblical examples like Abraham and the faithful saints (Romans 4:20-21; James 5:7-8; Galatians 3:29; Hebrews 11).

questions.question: By what means did God confirm His promise to Abraham, as described in Hebrews 6:13-14?
options: By an oath swearing by Himself
questions.correctAnswer: By an oath swearing by Himself
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:13-14 states God swore by Himself, since there is no greater, to confirm His promise to Abraham, underscoring the certainty and immutability of God's word (Genesis 22:16-18; Numbers 23:19; Psalm 89:34; Isaiah 55:11).

questions.question: What did Abraham obtain after patiently enduring, according to Hebrews 6:15?
questions.correctAnswer: The promise
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:15 highlights Abraham’s patience in faith leading to receiving the promise, illustrating the principle of perseverance in faith (Romans 4:20-22; James 1:4; Galatians 3:29; Hebrews 11:8-12).

questions.question: Why do men swear by the greater according to Hebrews 6:16?
options: To end all strife by confirming an oath
questions.correctAnswer: To end all strife by confirming an oath
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:16 explains that swearing by something greater is to settle disputes and confirm promises, reflecting ancient customs and God’s faithfulness (Genesis 21:23; Numbers 30:2; Psalm 89:35-37; 2 Corinthians 1:23).

questions.question: What was God's purpose in confirming His counsel with an oath according to Hebrews 6:17?
options: To show immutability of His counsel to heirs of the promise
questions.correctAnswer: To show immutability of His counsel to heirs of the promise
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:17 says God confirmed His promise by oath to demonstrate the unchangeable nature of His plan to the heirs, assuring believers of His faithfulness (Numbers 23:19; Psalm 33:11; Isaiah 40:8; James 1:17).

questions.question: What two immutable things provide strong consolation for those who flee to the hope set before us, according to Hebrews 6:18?
questions.correctAnswer: God's promise and His oath
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:18 identifies God's promise and His oath as two unchangeable guarantees providing strong encouragement for believers, comparable to God's steadfastness described in Isaiah 54:10; Numbers 23:19; Titus 1:2; Psalm 89:34.

questions.question: What is the hope described in Hebrews 6:19 compared to, illustrating its security for the soul?
options: An anchor both sure and steadfast
questions.correctAnswer: An anchor both sure and steadfast
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:19 compares hope to an anchor for the soul, firm and secure, entering the inner sanctuary, signifying stability in God's promises (Isaiah 33:6; Psalm 62:5-6; Job 11:18; 1 Corinthians 15:58).

questions.question: Who is described as the forerunner who has entered within the veil for us in Hebrews 6:20?
options: Jesus, made a high priest forever after the order of Melchisedec
Moses, the mediator of the Law
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus, made a high priest forever after the order of Melchisedec
questions.explanation: Hebrews 6:20 identifies Jesus as the forerunner who has entered the heavenly sanctuary as eternal high priest in Melchisedec’s order, emphasizing His superior priesthood (Psalm 110:4; Hebrews 7:1-3; 1 Timothy 2:5; Romans 8:34).
